title: Caithness Moray link is completed
story: THE Caithness-Moray electricity transmission link will support deployment of renewable energy in the north of Scotland for many years to come, the man who led the project has said.Dave Gardner, director of transmission for Scottish and Southern Electricity NetworksTransmission, was speaking after it was announced that the construction, commissioning and energisation of the link had been completed at a cost of around pound million.He hailed it as a signicant achievement for SSEN and everyone involved."Caithness-Moray has been a highly complex project, requiring very high standards of project design, development, construction and commissioning," Mr Gardner said. "It has been delivered by a team of committed and skilled people, working closely with contractors and other stakeholders."It will support deployment of renewable energy in the north of Scotland for many years to come."Now an operational asset, we will closely monitor the link and associated infrastructure to ensure its continued success as an integral part of the GB transmission system."We would like to thank all those who contributed to the success of the project, from our own teams of engineers and support staff, our supply chain and the local communities who have played host to our project teams over recent years."Caithness-Moray is the largest single investment ever undertaken by the SSE Group and is described as the most signicant investment in the north of Scotland electricity transmission system since the s.The link uses HVDCtechnology to transmit power through a km subsea cable beneath the Moray Firth seabed between new converter stations at Spittaland Blackhillock . Constructed over a period of four years, the project also involved work at eight electricity substation sites.Completed on time and within the allowance approved by the regulator Ofgem, the Caithness-Moray link provides up to MW of capacity to transmit power from the increasing sources of renewable energy from across the far north.The link has already enabled turbines from Beatrice offshore wind farmand Dorenell onshore wind farmto connect to the national grid with a further MW of onshore generation in Caithness and Ross-shire due to connect in the coming months.The completion of the link and other electricity transmission projects is expected to help take the Regulatory Asset Valueof SSEN Transmission to around pound. billion at March , .Sunday  Jan  : PM

title: Did aliens visit Wick
story: While millions of people around the country were cheering on the fireworks that brought in the new year, a Wick man and his family say they were witnessing a light show they never expected.Charlie Williamsonsays he had just popped out the back door of his house at Leishman Avenue after the bells sounded at midnight, only to spot a strange light overhead.He beckoned his we Tanya and their three children onto the doorstep from where he says they observed the strange object with flashing lights that ldquohovered in one place for over three hours.Speaking to the Courier, he says he wasnrsquot the only one to witness the eerie phenomenon.ldquoA local woman and some people south of the town also witnessed the strange sight.After Charlie posted a video of his sighting online, media ndash including the Scottish Sun ndash ran stories on his UFO experience.Many readers, however, wrote off the object as merely a drone.Charlie says he is ldquo per cent sure that is not the case.ldquoIt was way too big, he says. ldquoI donrsquot know much about drones other than the size of them but a few people have messaged me saying they wonrsquot fly for a solid three hours. It was windy that night too and a lot of people who fly drones have told me it wouldrsquove been too windy that night to fly one.Keith Banks, an amateur meteorologist who writes a monthly weather column for the John OrsquoGroat Journal, says mphgusts were blowing during the period the UFO was witnessed.ldquoIn my view the very blustery conditions would have effectively precluded a drone from flying, he said.Dedicated drone flyers agree, including Barry Scollay from Wick who says he has been flying the unmanned aerial vehicles for a decade.ldquoNo way a drone would have flown in those winds ndash thatrsquos a certain fact, said Mr Scollay, who has a Facebook page called Highland Aerial Views which has over , followersldquoIt would have to have been able to maintain its location in high winds. Irsquove flown very large drones in mph wind but that was the limit, he says.ldquoYou can [even] hear the wind howling in his video.Whatrsquos more, he says that software in operation at the nearby Wick airport would not allow such a drone to take off.Small hobby drones ldquocanrsquot fly within the airportrsquos no-fly zone.Charlie reckons the UFO was about ft above his head, larger than a car and made no sound.Although he took photos and video on his smartphone he admits that the quality was not the best.ldquoIt was like seeing a car at the bottom of your street, it was that clear. Itrsquos just not as clear with the phone.The object disappeared not long after a police van appeared at around am.ldquoI couldnrsquot get to sleep and kept going to the window and the door to see it but it was gone, he says.Since posting the video online he has had numerous calls from self-professed ldquoUFO investigators.Therersquos been so many of them, he says hersquos now ldquovery waryof callers who ask ldquotoo many questions.ldquoItrsquos like being interviewed by the FBI, he said. ldquoVery weird and over the top with the secrecy.Since his sighting, an organisation called the British Earth and Aerial Mysteries Societyhas said it believes he saw an ldquointerdimensional plasma craft.The craft have also been suggested as a cause for recent disruptions at Gatwick and Heathrow airports.A spokesperson for Wick John OrsquoGroats Airport confirmed that it was closed during the period the object was sighted, and there are also no reports of the emergency services operating in the air at that time.Charliersquos video can be seen at https:youtu.be xdHBiqtkWhat do you think he saw  Email d.scott@nosnwith your suggestions.Sunday  Jan  : PM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Sunday  Jan  : PM

title: Trailblazers on right path
story: MEMBERS of Wick Paths Group joined forces with Friends of the John OGroats Trail to improve a path used by walkers visiting the Castle of Old Wick.They got stuck in to the task of upgrading the narrow, muddy and uneven section from the old rle range to the field at the Grey Bools. The path had been scraped out in advance by Nordwall Landscaping to a width of . metres and some  tonnes of quarry gravel had been purchased and delivered to site.On the work day  volunteers turned out to help and they were grateful for the heavy machinery loaned by Hugh Simpson , M M Miller and Graham Begg. The gravel was laid in just under three hours and has resulted in a much-improved route.Wick Paths Group chairman Allan Tait said: "We are very grateful to all the volunteers who turned out to help, to the landowners for giving permission and to the local businesses for lending their equipment. The path is very popular with local people for walking and running as well as the increasing use by those walking the John OGroats Trail."This section of path is now immensely better than it was and I hope it will encourage many more people to come out and walk the route."Jay Wilson, chairman of the John OGroats Trail group, said: "Im very pleased to see a great turnout of Wick volunteers to build a path for the town that also forms part of the overall John OGroats Trail."Sunday  Jan  : PM

title: Upgrade should just be the start
story: THE pound. million upgrade of the north section of the Berriedale Braes should be the trigger to improve the rest of that part of the A, according to Caithness councillor Raymond Bremner.He made the plea after Transport Scotland confirmed the contract to upgrade the notorious north hairpin bend has been awarded to Dingwall-based engineering company R J McLeod Ltd. Work is due to start this year, be completed by spring  and create  jobs during the construction phase.Councillor Bremner, who represents Wick and East Caithness on Highland Council, said: "While Im keen to see an improvement to the north brae, I still believe we cant take our focus off the south brae. We have two major long-term concerns to focus on here ndash the gradient of the brae and the fact that we are still witnessing serious accidents on the bottom hairpin bend even where there is an escape bed."These accidents are a risk to le, causing road closures and impacting in all sorts of ways on our local community and economy. Improvements to the north brae are very welcome and I hope that it is the start of a bigger vision to improve the entire Berriedale Braes."We can expect the standard lead-in period of about three months and for discussions to be held with the contractor on how they propose to physically approach the works and discussions with statutory bodies like the Scottish Environment Protection Agency and the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds among others."He said that archaeological investigatory works have been completed.The award of the contract was also welcomed by Trudy Morris, chief executive of Caithness Chamber of Commerce.She said: "We are delighted to see that after many years of dedicated campaigning by the chamber, Caithness Transport Forum and other local organisations, this project is finally moving ahead. For too long, the Berriedale Braes has acted as a pinch point for travellers on the A north of Inverness, disrupting business and jeopardising investment in the region."It has been good to see other work on A improvements and repairs going to local companies in recent years, and we hope the principal contractor will engage closely with our highly skilled local supply chain as these works progress."Ms Morris added: "Now that the contract has been formally awarded, we hope to see clarication on exact start dates and expectedof works very soon. We would urge the Scottish Government to uphold its previous promise to start works within this financial year so that the north Highlands can start to see the benefit of this upgrade as soon as possible."A Transport Scotland spokesman said: "R J McLeod Ltd has been awarded the construction contract as part of the pound. million project to deliver improvements to the road alignment and the existing tight hairpin bend on the A."Michael Matheson, cabinet secretary for transport, hailed it as a positive development for the area. "It will enhance the skills development of the Scottish construction industry, with approximately  jobs expected to be supported in the region during construction."Related articles:Four in running for Berriedale Braes contractSilence on A schemeSunday  Jan  : PM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Sunday  Jan  : PM

title: Wicks Francis Street Club closes
story: Wick institution the Francis Street Club has been forced to close due to financial dficulties. ldquoIt was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , , the spokesperson, who did not wish to be named, said.A note subsequently posted on its door read: ldquoWe have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course.The building first opened as a British Legion in the s, and remained a popular focal point for the community.It served as a social club and ran football and darts teams ndash both well-supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.One famous occasion took place in  when Councillor Willie Mackay was able to persuade top darts players Jocky Wilson and Eric Bristow to play an exhibition match ndash a fixture Scotsman Wilson won.However, it is expected that such nights will now become a thing of the past.It is not known what the future of the building holds, orany parties are considering taking the club over.The spokesperson stressed the committee was ldquovery sad the club had to close.Sunday  Jan  : PM

title: invitation to tender issued for northern isles ferry contract
story: An Invitation to Tender for the next contract to run the Northern Isles ferry services has been issued to three bidders, the Scottish Government announced today, Thursday.Submission of final tenders is scheduled for March, with a view to awarding the contract in July.The contract is estimated to be worth £m and will run for eight years. The names of the companies involved have however, not been released.Minister for energy, connectivity and the islands, Paul Wheelhouse, said: “Issuing the Invitation to Tender marks the next stage of the process to award the new contract to operate the Northern Isles Ferry Services.“The contract will run for eight years, allowing us to build a strong working relationship with the successful bidder, and all the routes within the network are being tendered as a single bundle.“The Scottish Government remains fully committed to high quality ferry services to the Northern Isles. A key benefit of this new contract is the in-built flexibility, allowing the ferry services to be amended to reflect future changes in demand across the important sectors of the islands’ economies – tourism, fishing, food and drink, aquaculture and farming. Scottish Ministers will also retain control of all of important issues, such as fares and timetables, through the public service contract.“We are committed to a fair, open and transparent tender which aims to get the best possible deal for the communities that depend on these ferry services.”• Commenting on the issue, Northern Isles MSP’s Liam McArthur and Tavish Scott said: “The Scottish Government have finally issued the tender. The timescale is very tight indeed given the operator needs to be up and running the North Isles leline ferry services in  months’ time. It is essential that companies make constructive bids with improvements to the existing service. It must, in particular, recognise the growing freight volumes that are being exported south to the Scottish mainland.“So the tender bids must be properly assessed to ensure the service moves forward and not backwards. And the endless saga of RET must come to an end, otherwise how can bidding companies submit a proposed fare policy ”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: oic makes urgent call for ferry funding
story: Orkney Islands Council is again calling on the Scottish Government to honour a commitment to provide fully fair funding for the county’s inter-island ferry service — or it will hand the service back to the government to run.The council is warning it cannot afford to run the service during the year ahead unless the government covers the full cost involved — this amounts to £. million. OIC Leader James Stockan has notied Ministers that the council will hand over responsibility for running the service to Transport Scotland, unless sufficient funding is provided.A year ago, a similar level of support was secured, after a y campaign by OIC for fair funding. Of this, £. million was allocated to fully fund Orkney’s internal ferry service during the current financial year, with £ million awarded to Shetland Islands Council for its ferry operations.“But this time there is no specic amount allocated to Orkney or Shetland. The government recognises that it will cost £. million to operate our ageing fleet of ferries during - — and that is what we are asking the government to provide.”OIC is also looking to the government to fund the replacement of the current inter-island fleet. The council has been working with the government on this for a number of years and is currently developing a business case setting out the service levels local communities require, and the engineering options needed to achieve these.Councillor Stockan added: “We would object in the strongest possible termswe end up with a reduction in our ferries funding. This would place a wholly disproportionate and unfair burden on the smallest council in Scotland and would mean us having to make cuts to other vital services.“The ferries are a leline for remote and fragile communities across our islands. Orkney has the oldest fleet and the highest fares in the country — an inequality we cannot address without proper financial support from the Scottish Government.We are calling on the government to take an honourable approach to fulfilling the will of the Scottish Parliament that we should receive fair and equitable funding for our inter-island ferry service. The principle of transferring Orkney’s internal ferry service to the Scottish Government, at no net detriment to OIC, has already been approved by the council. That is a route we will have to take unless we are provided with the funds to run the service over the year ahead.”For the full story, pick up a copy of The Orcadian, this Thursday.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: Bid to get folk behind Dingwall improvement project
story: BUSINESSES keen to help regenerate Ross-shirersquos county town are being asked to show their support by getting surveys paving the way for a new development project lodged within days.The Dingwall Means Business group is behind plans for a business improvement districtwhich could mirror the success of a similar scheme in Inverness.BID manager George Murray said the group was now ldquowell into its year of listening and talking to all businesses in and around Dingwall to promote a lsquoyesrsquo for BID for the town.He said: ldquoNearly  surveys have gone out and we are still looking for a few more to be ed. The success of the Dingwall BID depends upon our local businessesrsquo support.ldquoWe are working hard to gather information from all the businesses in Dingwall and we need to hear from everyone. This is your chance to have your say and add to the overall business plan. Then all you have to do is vote yes in the ballot and we can make these projects happen.ldquoWe really want to make sure that nobody is missed and that everyone gets their opportunity to vote because this could be a monumental time in our townrsquos history. This could become the year when Dingwall businesses take control over the townrsquos economic future.Mr Murray said: ldquoWe are aware that there must be a decenton their investment. I believe Highland Council currently collect a wee bit more than pound million per annum from non-domestic ratepayers and Irsquove calculated that the levy would need to be between . to three per cent.ldquoThis would allow us to invoice the council for approximately pound,. Itrsquos also possible we would be able to almost match fund this figure from other sources. This would be an amazing amount banked in Dingwall to be spent on Dingwall. This is how we would fund the five-year plan ready to start after a yes vote.He wants remaining surveys, seeking feedback from businesses to a number of questions, ed by Friday, February .Survey results will then be collated with a five-year business plan set to be drafted by the end of March. A yes no vote on BID would then be held in May.Gordon McIntosh, practice manager of Munro  Noble, is a director of BID Inverness and believes the scheme can pay idends for Dingwall too.He said ldquocoach ambassadors had brought more tourists into the city, increasing spend. It meant local businesses were stakeholders in any centre development plans and have the ability to lobby the council over issues of interest. The scheme also paved the way for successful events such as classic car shows, Easter egg hunts and bar and business awards.He said: ldquoWith representatives from a cross section of businesses on the board the strong advocacy we have provided has achieved some notable results. These results have been for the betterment of our business and social community. A healthier, connected community drives profit opportunities.Sunday  Jan  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Business masterclass aims to put Highland entrepreneurs ahead
story: ENTREPRENEURS will learn how to create and sustain a competitive advantage at an event in Inverness next month.Professor Eleanor Shaw, executive director of the Hunter Centre for Entrepreneurship and vice dean of Strathclyde Business School, will deliver a masterclass on February  and  at the Kingsmills Hotel in Inverness.The event, which includes a networking dinner, is organised by Highlands and Islands Enterpriseas part of its entrepreneurship programme.Prof Shaw said: ldquoBy creating a competitive advantage, businesses can set a buffer between them and their competitors in turn creating a more secure place in the market.ldquoThe way in which we approach executive education at the University of Strathclyde is dferent ndash we put the focus on the participant in the room, looking at their needs and providing access to toolkits and learning so after the masterclass they can start working with colleagues and honing their value proposition straight away.ldquoEverything we do has been road tested by working with entrepreneurs and wersquove learned that creating a competitive advantage can help a business in many ways.ldquoIrsquom really looking forward to working with Highlands and Islands entrepreneurs, sharing our learnings and making new connections in the region.Louise MacDonald, senior entrepreneurship manager at HIE, said: ldquoCreating and sustaining a competitive advantage can be dficult in todayrsquos ever-changing and dynamic environment.ldquoBusinesses need to think strategically and be able to analyse their proposition to find ways to enhance impact, value and performance.ldquoThe masterclass will teach entrepreneurs from across the region the tools and techniques to stay ahead of the game.For more information, email entrepreneurship@hient or visit www.hie masterclassesSunday  Jan  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Conon Bridge school travel plan set for an upgrade
story: PARENTS of children in a village that has witnessed a surge in housebuilding are being asked to have their say on a new school travel plan.The appeal centres on Ben Wyvis Primary in Conon Bridge. A survey has been issued seeking information on issues such as what factors influence parentsrsquo decisions on whether to let their children walk or cycle to school and how much they value safer crossings, vehicle speed-reduction measures and improved road safety education as well as information on the benefits of walking and cycling.The survey includes questions about the distance pupils attending Ben Wyvis Primary live from the school and the modes of transport they use to get there.It also seeks views on measures that could reduce congestion at the school gate. These include involvement in voluntary cycle training and a car sharing scheme.Itrsquos part of a wider effort across the Highlands to work on safer routes to school, reduce unnecessary car use and encourage healthier alternatives where possible, such as walking and cycling.The survey, supported by the parent council, can be found online and completed at www.surveymonkey r BenWyvisPSSunday  Jan  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Easter Ross filmmaker turned author gets to art of matter in new novel
story: Tain-based Mike Herd had plenty of time to ponder plots when he worked as a cameraman on more than  films, many requiring endless patience to capture unforgettable footage.His latest novel, The Medusa Shield, is a ldquomystical fantasy set in the fictitious village of Rockburn on the eastern seaboard of the Black Isle. Set in , it sees protagonist Scott and his father James take the car ferry across the Beauly Firth to Inverness as they watch men working on the Kessock Bridge.Scott agrees to attend a farm roup with his father and feels he is being watched by a yellow eye from a dirty painting hanging amongst the lots. Unknown to his father, he successfully bids for it and his le starts to alter in remarkable ways.The action swings between Aberdeen and Florence as Scott embarks on a journey of discovery.Mr Herd, who describes himself as ldquo going on , said time spent alone working on so many films served him.He said: ldquoBy the nature of film work there wasnrsquot a typical day because all trips y. The most memorable film that I have worked on must be Swamp Tigers in the Bangladeshi Sundarbans.ldquoUsing a converted river ferry boat as a mobile base, a typical day would be, rising at four and travelling in the dark to a hide built on stilts embedded in a channel.ldquoI would stay there on my own usually for twelve hours and I did that for months. Being in a hide that long gives you plenty of time to think.ldquoLying awake in bed in the morning, plot ideas and characters nag at me and I have to get up to write about them.ldquoI am a hopeless two-fingered typist which is very frustrating because they canrsquot keep up with whatrsquos going through my head. That aside It does surprise me how easy it is for me to write, I donrsquot know where that comes from. I try to write at least a thousand words a day but quite often Irsquoll hit a brick wall.ldquoI donrsquot worry about that because I know that I will get the inspiration to carry on later.ldquoI try to write about what I know, itrsquos much more convincing and I use locations Irsquove been to. For example, in The Medusa Shield, Scott goes full moon night fishing off the Black Isle coast in a Zulu boat. While I was in India the fishermen on the east coast do that every month.The Medusa Shield is available from Amazon Kindle, Kobo and other digital publishers.Sunday  Jan  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Fresh deal is a sign of our intent says firm at Invergordon port
story: A MAJOR engineering firmrsquos decision to extend its contract at the Port of Cromarty Firth is a sign of its ldquocommitment to the area and wider UK market, its operations manager has said,Offshore project and engineering company Semco Maritimersquos decision to extend its use of the portrsquos Queens Dock facility follows its busiest ever year.In  ious vessels stayed in Queens Dock along with Maersk Reacher, which received reactivation upgrades over  months, and Maersk Innovator, which spent two months on site for the upgrade and installation of a cantilever extension.In the five years it has operated at the site Semco Maritime has carried out works on drilling rigs, pipe lay vessels, accommodation rigs, survey vessels, cargo boats and ious other projects, and has hosted numerous rigs.ldquoThe extension of our existing contract for Queens Dock shows Semco Maritimersquos commitment to maintain and strengthen our presence in the UK, said Neil Robertson, operations manager at Semco Maritime, Invergordon.ldquoWe have seen our department in Invergordon flourish and deliver great service to our clients, not least thanks to a productive agreement with Port of Cromarty Firth with both parties fully behind repairs, upgrades and maintenance projects,The firm described Invergordon as a perfect base for ious offshore service projects, which had made it possible to carry out repairs, upgrades and maintenance for rigs in operation as far away as Malaysia, Australia and the Gulf of Mexico.Bob Buskie, chief executive of the Port of Cromarty Firth said Semco Maritimersquos presence ldquohas made Invergordon an attractive port for drilling contractors and subsea operators undertaking inspection, repair and maintenance projects.Sunday  Jan  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Highland arts venue has strategy to combat fund gap
story: THE regionrsquos biggest arts venue has outlined how it must become more financially resilient.In its latest accounts, Eden Court in Inverness reported increased income and more expenditure in the year ending March ,  compared to the previous  months.Last year Eden Court lost pound, a year of funding ndashpound, from Creative Scotland and pound, from the Highland Council.A trusteesrsquo report the figures stated: ldquoThe principal risks identied are financial ones, particularly the effect of this yearrsquos signicant reduction in public funding.ldquoThe organisation must become more financially resilient by growing sources of earned income and building a safe level of reserves.ldquoAs public funding declines, the targets for earnings from trading activities necessarily increase, and the risk that these targets cannot be met also increases. At the same time, our cost base is likely to increase owing to inflationary pressures on resources.ldquoThis year we are working on a strategy for trading through our funding gap, increasing income from charitable trading, reducing costs wherever possible and developing partnerships to share services.ldquoAttention has also been focused on non-financial risks arising from the loss of some channels of regular communication with our major funders our relationship with both Creative Scotland and the Highland Council has been strengthened during the year to March ,  and subsequently.ldquoThe development of positive relationships with funders ndash public organisations and inidual philanthropists ndash remains a high priority and is a central part of Eden Courtrsquos financial strategy for the coming three years.Total income increased from pound,, in  to pound,, last year. For the same period, total expenditure moved from pound,, to pound,,.Total funds also went up from pound,, to pound,,.Advance ticket sales mean that Eden Courtrsquos cash flow position remains strong.The biggest event of the year was the Snow White panto, which sold more than , tickets for its  performances.The report stated: ldquoAttendance for the year has been unprecedented with audiences of , for live performances and , at film screenings. The financial contribution from live performances was pound, higher than budget, boosted by some musical performances in the summer months and an excellent result from our Christmas pantomime.The wholly owned subsidiary Eden Court Trading experienced a rise in turnover from pound,, in  to pound,, last year, and an increase in pre-tax profit from pound, to pound,.The report added: ldquoOver the past four years we have seen substantial growth in trading through our restaurant, cafeacute and bars, and also in sales of confectionary, show merchandise and programmes by our front of house team.ldquoOur trading activities in   resulted in a surplus of pound,, an increase of  per cent over the previous yearrsquos result.ldquoWe will also implement a new strategy to attract philanthropy from trusts and foundations, and from within our community.Sunday  Jan  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Hopes for future of shelved Dingwall fish factory
story: HOPES are high another manufacturer will swoop into Dingwall and start afresh in the building being vacated by the Edinburgh Salmon Company .The base where  people lost their jobs at the end of last month is on sale for an undisclosed sum.Dingwall councillor Margaret Paterson believes the vast majority of the laid off workers will stay put in Dingwall in the hope another venture will open soon.She said: ldquoMany of those people have lived in Dingwall for years and years theyrsquove got staying power, theyrsquore hard workers. Theyrsquove got homes here, their children go to school here theyrsquove made Dingwall their home. You donrsquot leave your home without putting up a really hard fight.Fellow ward councillor Alister Mackinnon understands several companies have been eyeing-up the building but doubts the scale of any future fish processing organisation would match ESCorsquos operation.A spokesman for the firm, which opened in Dingwall in , said: ldquoWe are exploring all possible avenues regarding a potential sale of the facilities.It would not ulge further details, citing commercial sensitivity. title: Invergordon garden project wins a reprieve

title: Life saving Ross shire Womens Aid centre issues action plan after mixed report
story: The Dingwall-based Ross-shire Womenrsquos Aid centre has received a mixed inspection report from the Care Commission watchdog.While the quality of care and support provided to abused women and their children was judged good, the quality of management and leadership was rated ldquoadequate.One woman told inspectors that the service was a le-saver and she wished it would receive more funding.However there were times when staff felt inadequately supported by management, said the report following the unannounced inspection. The report stated: ldquoSince our last inspection there had been changes within the management team and this had impacted on the overall quality of service provision.ldquoThe service provider acknowledged this was an area that they were under-performing in and as a result, an interim management team had recently been put in place. We met with the interim management team and noted that good progress was being made to address many areas we identied as needing improvement. We were also provided with a detailed action plan which identied immediate and future areas for improvement.ldquoAs a result of our findings we concluded that the service was currently operating to an adequate standard. Should we have found that the recent management team were not making signicant in-roads to address our concerns we would have graded the management and leadership as weak.ldquoWhen we spoke with staff, all said that they had been faced with many challenges and that there were times when they felt totally unsupported by management.It said staff continued to work in a dedicated and caring way, were well trained and experienced.It added: ldquoHowever, we were also aware that staff had been faced with a challenging time due to changes in the management of the service. This had clearly impacted on staff morale and a feeling of being unsupported at times. We have highlighted this as an area that needs to be improved on in the management and leadership theme in this report.Eight women who responded to the inspection questionnaires were happy overall with the quality of care and support provided.During the inspection comments noted included: ldquoThe service from Womenrsquos Aid is a le-saver ldquoMy care worker has supported me through the worst and shown me how far I have come, and ldquoI just wish they could get more funding so they can continue to provide this le-saving service.Sunday  Jan  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Muir of Ord pupils go purple for inspirational Beth
story: BIG-hearted pupils at a Ross-shire school showed their true colours in a poignant show of solidarity with an inspiratinal "one in a million" classmate suffering from a rare condition.Tarradale Primary pupil Beth Cameron was diagnosed with chronic recurring multocal osteomyelitis , a rare condition affecting around one in a million children in which the bones have lesions, inflammation and pain.Classmates decided to show their support for Beth by inviting pupils to wear something purple last Friday ndash whether that be ribbon, socks, t-shirt or jumper. Beth was greeted by a sea of purple when she turned up at school.Head teacher Tracy Sinclair took to Facebook to explain to parents: "Our perfect Beth is blazing a trail. We talked a lot about barriers to learning and le. Sleeping in. Days off. Lateness. title: Support blooms for Invergordon garden project
story: A BID to save an under-threat gardening project for learning disabled adults in Easter Ross has won public support amid growing efforts to secure its long-term future.NHS Highland has withdrawn its funding for the initiative at the Isobel Rhind Centre in Invergordon, saying it cannot afford it.But at least , people have signed a petition backing the initiative and more than pound of a pound, target to fund a six-month extension has been raised thanks to the support of well-wishers responding to a crowdfunding drive set up by Cromarty Firth councillor Maxine Smith.A local businessman has also promised to match fund whatever is raised through the drive.Cllr Smith said thateveryone who signed the petition chipped in just pound, it would ensure a breathing space for the  users who have helped brighten up Invergordon with hanging baskets.Efforts to find a new model to deliver the scheme have been going on behind the scenes and NHS Highland has said that although funding will stop, the land at the centre can continue to be used. However, health chiefs have been accused of dragging their feet over helping to find a sustainable future model to deliver the scheme, which many of the users have said gives them a reason to get up in the morning.The project leader, who is employed by High Le Highland, has been told funding will end this month. According to Cllr Smith, garden users are ldquodevastated but adamant they wish to continue.She wants to see NHS Highland play a full role plotting the way forward, including carrying out self-directed supportassessments, a tool that aims to ensure people who are eligible for support are given the choice and control over how their inidual budget is arranged and delivered to meet their agreed health and social care outcomes.Tain-based Mike Herd, whose son has happily attended the scheme in Invergordon, said: ldquoNHS Highland made a commitment to me last year that they would try to help the garden project continue through a dferent funding formula. However, the reality is that letters asking for SDS funding have been ignored. It seems that NHS Highland have just abandoned the gardeners to a bleak futurelong-term funding cannot be agreed.Cllr Smith added: ldquoI make a plea, especially to big businesses locally, to contact me and offer some funding towards this worthwhile project that gives the adult users with learning disabilities pride and a reason to get up in the morning.ldquoIt is only a one-off payment I am seeking, not continual funding.NHS Highlandrsquos head of service for learning disabilities and autism, Arlene Johnstone, said: ldquoDue to financial pressures NHS Highland is no longer able to contribute funding to the Garden Project in Invergordon. However, we are supporting Councillor Maxine Smith in her efforts to find a new funding model and we have offered that,successful, they can continue to use the land in the grounds of the Isobel Rhind Centre. We have also introduced her to colleagues who have been able to advise of potential ways forward.ldquoNHS Highland is committed to ensuring that people with a learning disability can participate fully in our communities and therefore are also in discussion with High Le Highland and Councillor Maxine Smith to explore alternative ways of providing the activity that people enjoy. This could be a social enterprise that would provide paid employment in exchange for the work that the people who attend the Garden Project do for their local community.The petition and link to the crowdfinding page can be found at https:tinyurl yaclerfuSunday  Jan  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Walk on the wild side inspires Tain writers new book
story: A FILMMAKER turned author who has drawn on a letime of experiences around the world for his work has been inspired by locations much closer to his Easter Ross home for his latest novel.Tain-based Mike Herd had plenty of time to ponder plots when he worked as a cameraman on more than  films, many requiring endless patience to capture unforgettable footage.His latest novel, The Medusa Shield, is a ldquomystical fantasy set in the fictitious village of Rockburn on the eastern seaboard of the Black Isle. Set in , it sees protagonist Scott and his father James take the car ferry across the Beauly Firth to Inverness as they watch men working on the Kessock Bridge.Scott agrees to attend a farm roup with his father and feels he is being watched by a yellow eye from a dirty painting hanging amongst the lots. Unknown to his father, he successfully bids for it and his le starts to alter in remarkable ways.The action swings between Aberdeen and Florence as Scott embarks on a journey of discovery.Mr Herd, who describes himself as ldquo going on , said time spent alone working on so many films served him.He said: ldquoBy the nature of film work there wasnrsquot a typical day because all trips y. The most memorable film that I have worked on must be Swamp Tigers in the Bangladeshi Sundarbans.ldquoUsing a converted river ferry boat as a mobile base, a typical day would be, rising at four and travelling in the dark to a hide built on stilts embedded in a channel.ldquoI would stay there on my own usually for twelve hours and I did that for months. Being in a hide that long gives you plenty of time to think.ldquoLying awake in bed in the morning, plot ideas and characters nag at me and I have to get up to write about them.ldquoI am a hopeless two-fingered typist which is very frustrating because they canrsquot keep up with whatrsquos going through my head. That aside It does surprise me how easy it is for me to write, I donrsquot know where that comes from. I try to write at least a thousand words a day but quite often Irsquoll hit a brick wall.ldquoI donrsquot worry about that because I know that I will get the inspiration to carry on later.ldquoI try to write about what I know, itrsquos much more convincing and I use locations Irsquove been to. title: brexit theresa may s inflexibility is weakening the union anand menon
story: Theresa May#s inflexibility over her Brexit #red lines# is widening the schism between Edinburgh and London, writes Professor Anand Menon.Trust, or more precisely a lack of it, has been central to the Brexit process. Its absence soured debates over the rights of EU citizens. It also explains the bitterness over arguments about the Irish backstop. And it is an absence of trust that has shaped relations between London and Edinburgh since June .As Theresa May casts about for support for her Brexit deal, her latest appeal has been to the Scottish, Welsh and indeed Northern Irish parties in Westminster. Speaking in the House of Commons on  January, she declared that while “it will always be for Her Majesty’s Government to negotiate for the whole of the UK, we are also committed to giving the devolved administrations an enhanced role in the next phase, respecting their competence and vital interests in these negotiations”.On the surface, this was a sensible offer. What really matters in terms of the long-term future of the country is not the Withdrawal Agreement currently stuck in parliamentary gridlock, but the future UK-EU relationship. In offering this ‘enhanced’ role to the devolved administrations, the Prime Minister was trying to dilute their opposition to the former with the promise of consultation over the latter. However, as Professor Nicola McEwen noted, Scotland and Wales don’t even get a passing mention in the political declaration, despite it having massive implications for devolved policy areas.Having proffered an olive branch, May then proceeded to snatch it away. After a meeting in Downing Street last week, the First Minister reported that the Prime Minister “was keener to rule out the things she wasn’t prepared to do – extend Article , contemplate a second EU referendum” than to discuss the red lines she had laid down unilaterally back in .Indeed, the UK Government’s only substantive offer was for Nicola Sturgeon and Mark Drakeford to attend new Cabinet sub-committee meetings on preparing for the UK’s exit from the EU. “Watch us implement policies we defined despite your objections” is hardly the most enticing proposition.: Brexit: Philip Hammond refuses to rule out quitting in event of no-dealSo far, so predictable. This is typical May. It has been a striking — and, at least since she lost her majority in , dysal — aspect of her style that she is more comfortable ruling options out than opening them up. She has proved happy to make concessions on process as long as it is process heading in a direction she alone has determined.Think back for a second. Immediately after moving into Downing Street, May made her first visit as Prime Minister to Scotland. She stressed her willingness to listen to options and declared her wish to see the Scottish Government “fully engaged in our discussion”. She then proceeded to lay down a series of red lines that directly contradicted the expressed preferences of the Scottish Government to stay in the single market and customs union.The UK Government then published its EUBill, which managed to unite Carwyn Jones and Nicola Sturgeon in describing it as a “naked power grab” by Westminster.The Withdrawal Bill underlined not only the fragility of the devolution settlement, but also the willingness of London to tinker with it as it saw fit. PersonallyI suspect this was more an overwhelmed civil service trying to simply the Brexit process rather than a deliberate attempt to sabotage devolution.: Brexit: Why People’s Vote campaign is failing – Paris GourtsoyannisWhatever the truth, the Withdrawal Bill involved the relocation of powers previously held in Belfast, Cardf and Edinburgh to London as “retained EU law”. The Scottish Parliament refused consent for the EUBill and passed its own Continuity Bill, and the UK Government took the Scottish Government to the Supreme Court. The latter ruled before Christmas that the Bill was legitimate, but that placing requirements on UK ministers was not. Negotiations in court rooms, as opposed to smoke-filled rooms, is rarely a recipe for building trust.Meanwhile, in December MSPs voted by  to  to reject Theresa May’s Brexit deal. Whatever happens in Westminster, evenTheresa May can Houdini herself out of the current bind, this will not be a Brexit deal that has the consent of all parts of the UK.As one might expect, the handling of Brexit by the Government in London has not endeared May to the Scottish public. A large majority are less than impressed by the Prime Minister, with  per cent believing she is doing badly or very badly. By last October, a majorityalso viewed her either unfavourably or very unfavourably. That’s not to say Nicola Sturgeon has had things all her own way either. Brexit and what many view as the shoddy treatment of the devolved settlement has not translated into increased support for independence. As researcher Ian Montagu has explained, this has remained remarkably stable, despite increasing irritation at the Government in Westminster. And the SNP faces a dilemma of their own: according to the Scottish Social Attitudes survey, around half of independence supporters are also Eurosceptic. Between  and , the SNP’s support among this group fell by  percentage points while remaining steady among Europhiles.The creation of this schism in Sturgeon’s electoral coalition is a political problem for the SNP. Yet, May’s uncompromising style, and an inability to build up trust in the last two years, has deepened the schism between Westminster and Edinburgh. The Prime Minister’s inability to build trust through compromise could well be the character flaw that trumps her unionist instincts.Anand Menon is director of The UK in a Changing Europeand professor of European politics and foreign affairs at King’s College London. He’s on Twitter @anandmenon©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: euan mccolm a week that put second independence referendum in mothballs
story: Sorry, were having problems with our video player at the moment, but are working to fix it as soon as we canWaiting for Video...Since becoming First Minister after the Yes campaign#s defeat in the  Scottish independence referendum, Nicola Sturgeon has never missed an opportunity to proclaim the need for a re-match.Any and all political developments have been greeted by her as evidence that the people of Scotland simply must be given another opportunity to vote on leaving the United Kingdom. Even when this strategy has demonstrably proved damaging – both Sturgeon and Deputy First Minister John Swinney conceded that the promiseof indyref played its part in the nationalists’ loss of  seats in the  general election – the First Minister has found it impossible to remove this particular record from the turntable.: Nicola Sturgeon: Scottish independence is “bigger than” Alex SalmondWhen times are bad  Then independence is the only way to improve the lot of the Scot. When times are good  Imagine how much better they’d be with independence.Most recently, the chaos of Brexit has been held up by Sturgeon as a compelling reason for the break-up of the UK. The very integrity of our democracy would be threatened by the refusal of the British government to facilitate indyref.Recently, Sturgeon has promised that she will soon set out her thinking on a second independence referendum. Enthusiastic SNP members have taken this to mean it’s game-on for another vote on the constitution.They are kidding themselves.Recent weeks have been, to put things mildly, dficult for the independence movement. Tensions between Sturgeon and her predecessor, Alex Salmond, have bubbled to the surface and created a civil war in the SNP.The instability of this situation should have been enough to force the First Minister to put the brake on the indyref bus. After all, a campaign ided is a campaign that will lose.But evenshe continued, through the recriminations, to harbour the hope that another referendum might be both achievable and winnable, events of the past week – Salmond’s arrest and subsequent court appearance on serious charges – must surely have convinced her to revise her assessment.For some in the SNP – and I speak of people who consider themselves loyal to Sturgeon – the dream of a swt indyref is dead. “We can’t, with everything that is happening, contemplate another referendum,” says one. “We got close to winning in  because we had a tight, well-disciplined campaign. Nobody serious in the SNP could argue that the time is right to kick things off again. People’s minds are where.”From another smart Nat comes the suggestion that Sturgeon should only continue with her plan to lay out her thinking on indyrefshe intends to clearly put it on indefinite hold. The game of “mebbes aye, mebbes naw” must come to an end and the FM should make it clear her priority is on domestic policy rather than constitutional wrangling.I find it impossible to disagree with the assessment of these party insiders that the SNP not in a good place, right now. How could anyone And, this being so, their wish for Sturgeon to press pause on her referendum plans makes perfect sense. It is often forgotten in the heat of constitutional argument that the Scottish Government does not have the power to hold an independence referendum. Sturgeon – as was the case with her predecessor – would require the agreement of the UK government before putting the constitutional question to the people.Recent Sturgeon rhetoric has pointed to her planning a politically expedient battle with Westminster over this point. The FM has spoken repeatedly about her desire to have that authority transferred from London to Edinburgh.In normal circumstances, this battle – one that Sturgeon would lose – might have made sense. The narrative that Westminster dictates rather than listens to the Scottish parliament has served the SNP well in the recent past.But circumstances are not normal and the FM would be open to the charge that such a fight with the UK government was little more than a ersionary tactic. And a tawdry one at that.There has been, among pragmatists in the SNP, some frustration in recent years with the First Minister’s constant pandering to the more excitable among independence supporters. Many feel that, every time she plays to the gallery of the already convinced, she turns off those who –independence is ever to be won – must be persuaded to change their minds. This feeling is sharper than ever right now.I have a great deal of sympathy for those in the SNP who believe Sturgeon should, in recent years, have taken for granted the support of hardcore nationalists. After all, where  are these voters to go  A steady – even cautious – approach to the constitutional argument might not be to their taste but they are unlikely to change their minds on the key question of whether Scotland should be independent. Their votes are already in the bag.Some might feel any declaration by Sturgeon that plans for indyref are on hold would represent a humiliation. I would argue that fighting to stage a vote and then losing it would be a far more damaging course of events.The First Minister has repeatedly said she wishes to be judged on her government’s stewardship of Scotland’s education system. This must become her real priority.The SNP is now deep in crisis and things stand to get very much worse before they get better. If Sturgeon and her party are to survive the months ahead and come out the other end as contenders to win a fourth Holyrood election, she must concentrate on proving to cautious “middle Scotland” voters that the SNP is about more than constitutional wrangling.“It might not be what the independence and nothing less mob wants to hear,” says one activist, “but it is absolutely what has to be donethey’re ever to get what they want.”When Sturgeon succeeded Salmond as First Minister in , she promised to be a leader for all, not just for the pro-independence minority. Circumstances dictate that she must live up to those words. If she doesn’t, the chances of Scots ever voting yes to independence will grow increasingly slender.©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: brexit saps support for scottish independence claim unionists
story: Sorry, were having problems with our video player at the moment, but are working to fix it as soon as we canWaiting for Video...Brexit is turning Scots against independence, which is seen as an #alien concept# to many young voters in the new, globally connected world, according to the head of the pro-Union campaign. Scotland in Union chief Pamela Nash says it’s “very clear” that Scotland will reject independence as Nicola Sturgeon prepares to set out her plans for a second referendum in the coming weeks. And the prospect of the SNP government seeking to hold its own “Catalonia-style” vote without the authority of Westminster, which has control over the constitution, would be a mistake, she warns.: Euan McColm: A week that put second independence referendum in mothballsBut the claims on voting intentions have been rejected by the SNP, which insists that polling evidence indicates young voters are moving towards Yes.: RT to continue broadcasting Alex Salmond chat showThe pro-Union campaign has stepped up activity in recent months with town hall meetings, high street stalls and a presence at a range of other events. Sturgeon cranked up the pressure on Theresa May on the independence issue at Downing Street last week, suggesting the Prime Minister is afraid of the verdict of the Scottish people.The nationalist government says that Scots deserve an alternative to the Brexit chaos and will increasingly be driven towards supporting independence.But Nash, a former Labour MP, said: “It’s having the opposite impact on people’s views on another independence referendum in Scotland.“People see the chaos that has ensued and they don’t feel that they need more constitutional chaos with another independence referendum in Scotland.“We see very clearly now the dficulties of breaking up decades of political union, but those dficulties would be exponentially biggerwe were breaking up a centuries-old union.“The UK is an important political union, but it’s not just that, it’s the economy and, most importantly, it’s our shared culture and history. “I can understand why that question is being asked, but it’s just not what we’re seeing and it’s also not what’s playing out in the polls either.“Polling has not moved in every single poll that was taken over the past year.“People see those dferences and they actually want stability. They don’t want to go through even more turmoil.”According to Nash, the recent feedback from meetings around the country and events like Glasgow and Edinburgh Pride is that Brexit has altered the views of many about Scotland being in the UK.She said: “They don’t want to cut off those opportunities and they want to keep that as open as possible. That has had a big impact which the SNP has not reflected.“The world has continued to become increasingly interconnected. We were making these arguments in , but that has developed much, much faster than we would have anticipated,” said Nash. “That is the argument we will be putting to the younger generation as well – that it’s an alien concept to put up more barriers and borders when the world is much  more interconnected when we want to travel and we want to work with people throughout the world when we’re sitting in our own living rooms. “I’ve spoken to young people who since Brexit have changed their minds on the support they had for Scotland being independent before – it made them think again.”But the SNP insists the most recent polling from Panelbase indicates  per cent of Scots aged  to  would vote Yes in an independence referendum. This has steadily increased over the past year as the Brexit chaos has intensied, according to surveys from a iety of pollsters.Nationalist MSP George Adam dismissed Nash’s claims as “demonstrably untrue”.“This simply exposes how rattled the SiU are by the consistent polling which shows that – by a factor of two to one – young Scots overwhelmingly back independence,” he said.Scotland in Union formed in early  as the dust settled on the previous year’s independence referendum. Its aim was to make the pro-Union case as support for the SNP soared. But despite the political upheaval of the past four years, the one constant has been the level of support for independence, which has remained broadly around the same  per cent level it stood at when the referendum was held.“There’s a need for Scotland to continually make the positive case for remaining in the United Kingdom, which could easily be lost at the moment with everything that’s going on,” said Nash. The fact is that it’s still the best way forward for Scotland’s future to have increased stability and opportunities and the global influence of being part of the UK.“We do need a continued campaign to make that case. The polls haven’t changed much, but we would want to increase support further.”For those who might be tempted to vote for Scotland to leave the UK as a means of rejoining the European Union, Nash said there was no easy route to becoming a member. “The evidence points towards a y application process with no guarantees at the end,” she said.Recent weeks have seen senior SNP figures such as former deputy leader Jim Sillars and MP Pete Wishart urge a more cautious approach to a second referendum until the case has been made and victory looks assured.But Sturgeon is also facing growing calls from grassroots activists and the Greens at Holyrood to forge ahead and call a second vote.The First Minister has been accused of “playing to the gallery” in recent statements on the issue.“For any party leader there’s an element of having to keep their own supporters onside – there’s no doubt that’s what Nicola is doing,” said Nash.Similarly Sturgeon’s pledge to announce her timetable has been put back a number of times as the Brexit chaos ensued.“We were first expecting that last June and that’s continued. It keeps getting put off every few weeks,” said Nash.The Scottish Government has always been clear in public that the  referendum – held after a Section  order was agreed with Westminster – was the “gold standard” for holding such votes. But recent weeks have seen suggestions from leading SNP figures to look at the option of a “Catalan-style” referendum, which would see a vote staged “illegally” by the Scottish Government without a Section  order from Westminster. Reports have even indicated that the Scottish Government is seeking legal advice on such a move.“I think that would be a very silly move from the Scottish Government to go ahead and do that,” said Nash.©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: nicola sturgeon scottish independence is bigger than alex salmond
story: Sorry, were having problems with our video player at the moment, but are working to fix it as soon as we canWaiting for Video...Criminal charges against Alex Salmond do not damage the case for independence, Nicola Sturgeon has said.The First Minister insisted that the campaign for an independent Scotland was “bigger than any one man”.Her predecessor as First Minister and SNP leader was told this week he faces  charges including attempted rape, indecent assault and breach of the peace. Mr Salmond says he is “innocent of any criminality whatsoever” and will contest the charges.: Euan McColm: A week that put second independence referendum in mothballsAppearing on the Andrew Marr show, Ms Sturgeon refused to say whether she had been contacted by police in connection with the case.“I will not comment on any aspect of the police investigation,” she said. “That is not a matter of choice necessarily, those are the obligations I like everybody  are under to respect due process.“I am not going to comment… it would not be appropriate for me to do so.”The First Minister rejected the suggestion that the charges against Mr Salmond had damaged the independence cause, claiming that Brexit had “strengthened that case immeasurably”.“No, I don’t think it has an impact on the future political and constitutional direction of Scotland,” she said.“The case for independence is bigger than any one man. It’s bigger than any one woman.“It’s not about inidual personalities, it’s about what is best for the country now and in the longer term. It’s about how we put ourselves in the best position to protect our interests and build prosperity and fairness in Scotland.: Brexit saps support for Scottish independence, claim Unionists “That’s a case that obviously the SNP is in the leading position in making, but it’s a case that over the last few years has won many converts and the experience of the last two and a half years of Brexit - we face being taken out of the EU against our will, the views of Scotland have been largely disregarded - I think has strengthened that case immeasurably.”Jackson Carlaw, the interim Scottish Conservative leader said: “Only one thing was clear from Nicola Sturgeon’s evasive performance this morning.“No matter what happens within her own party or where, she won’t stop banging on and on about her campaign for another independence referendum. “That is her only priority.”Amid continuing Brexit deadlock, the First Minister has promised to reveal details of her timetable for a second independence referendum “within weeks”.Pressed on whether the  March Brexit date was a “deadline” by which she would be forced to make an announcement, Ms Sturgeon said it would come “within that timeframe”.©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: scotland s global reputation at highest level for ten years
story: Scotland has achieved its highest score for ten years in an international comparison study despite falling one place in a list of  nations.The Anholt-GfK Roper Nation Brands IndexSM is used by the Scottish Government to monitor how Scotland is perceived around the world.The latest report puts Scotland in th position after looking at its reputation based on exports, governance, culture, people, tourism, immigration investment.The result represents a fall of one place on the previous year, despite the overall score of . being the highest achieved since .According to the study, Germany is the top nation, while Japan is second and the UK is third. The rest of the top ten was made up of France, Canada, Italy, United States, Switzerland, Sweden and Australia.Scotland’s strong “dimensions”, according to the study, were tourism and governance, which ranked Scotland th and th in the world, respectively. Scotland’s weakest dimension was exports, where it was ranked rd out of .Natural beauty continues to be perceived as Scotland’s strongest characteristic, ranking seventh out of the  nations and it ranked th in relation to how welcoming the people are.Overall, people in the  years and over and  to  years age group had a more positive image of Scotland than those in the  to  years age group, with those aged  years and over having the most positive image of Scotland across five out of the six dimensions. The more exposure people have had to Scotlandthe more likely they were to be favourable towards Scotland, and to score Scotland higher on all the dimensions. A Scottish Government spokeswoman said: “Scotland continues to be viewed positively by people from all over the world, with our warm welcome to tourists, our strong governance and our people all scoring well.“Scotland’s score in the  Nation Brand Index is the highest score it has received since the baseline study of , improving from . in  to . in .”©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: scottish woman lost her baby after she was misdiagnosed with a stomach bug
story: A pregnant woman suffering from appendicitis lost her baby after doctors at a scandal-hit hospital misdiagnosed her with a stomach bug.The woman, who has not been named but was referred to as ‘Mrs C’, was admitted to the Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow for treatment.The ‘super-hospital’, which is one of the largest in Europe, is under scrutiny after it emerged that two patients including a ten-year-old boy died following an infection linked to pigeon droppings.NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde has admitted there were “clear failings” in the expectant mother’s care, after a damning report was published.The woman was admitted to hospital with severe abdominal pain and suspected appendicitis.An ultrasound was carried out and she was treated for gastroenteritis, commonly referred to as ‘stomach flu’.However, her condition deteriorated and she developed sepsis - and doctors discovered that her unborn baby had died.An inquiry found there was a catalogue of failures in the woman’s care including no review by an experienced obstetrician and a “lack of physical examination” by experienced doctors. - Academy refuses to pull James Bulger film from Oscars despite family’s pleaChecks on her vital signs including blood pressure, respiratory and heart rate were “not done appropriately” and there was a failure to interpret the signs of sepsis.The reason for her deteriorating condition was discovered when she was opened up in the operating theatre and her appendix was removed.However she later developed sepsis and organ failure.The patient recovered after treatment but was readmitted twice more with infections in her abdominal muscles.The Scottish Public Services Ombudsmanupheld a complaint that there was an “unreasonable failure” to diagnose appendicitis and sepsis.Doctors were said to have failed to adequately consider an alternative diagnosis to gastroenteritis and consideration should have been given to carrying out a CT scan or laparoscopy.The board was also criticised for delays in launching an investigation into the incident.A spokesman for the SPSO said: “There was an unreasonable failure to diagnose Mrs C with both appendicitis and sepsis and, therefore, upheld Mrs C’s complaints.“A number of failings had been identied by the board, but we made some additional recommendations for learning and improvement.”The hospital has been told to apologise to the patient and review the care of deteriorating patients, particularly those exhibiting signs of sepsis, with patients “escalated” to a senior doctor. - Father of schoolgirl calls for law change after claiming: Instagram killed my daughter A spokesman for NHSGCC said: “We recognise there were clear failings in the patient’s care and will write to the patient to apologise.“The Ombudsman’s recommendations are being discussed by a multi-disciplinary team to identy how these can be quickly implemented and ensure that lessons learned in this case are shared with appropriate staff.” - Kevan Christie: Glasgow’s superhospital has all the symptoms of sick hospital syndrome©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: help for families feeling the pinch after christmas
story: The Scottish government plea is being made as it was revealed that about half a million people across the country are not claiming all the support they are entitled to.Impartial advice is available through the government-funded Financial Health Check scheme provided by Citizens Advice.The health checks were launched in November and cabinet secretary for communities Aileen Campbell said: “Too many people are not accessing everything they could be, and we want to ensure the right support is there to help people make the most of their financial situation.#The service will cover issues such as access to free school meals, benefit uptake, council tax reduction and cheaper deals on energy and other utilities to reduce household costs.“If you’re a parent struggling to make ends meet, you’re not alone. It doesn’t matteryou’re in work or out, one call to the free phone line is all it takes get some advice that could make a real dference.#Citizens Advice Scotland chief executive Derek Mitchell said, #large numbers of families in Shetland are still not claiming support they are entitled to# adding that there may be ways to alleviate the financial pressure and ensure everyone #can access their basic rights to food and a warm home for their families.”Would like to see both the Shetland Council and LPAto be more pro active at flag flying from the Town Hall senior flag staff and the LPA at Victoria Pier. Many thousands of observers from around the world monitor Lerwick on the Shetland webcams and it is rare to see a flag flying from the Town Hall. The Town Hall flag staff with no flag flying is like a community with no heart.I would say that flags are pretty low on the list of priorities for those finding it dficult to heat their homes or feed their children!..

title: minister hears plea for debts to be written off
story: Locum costs, hospital bed closures because of staffing shortages and staff retention were among the issues discussed at NHS Shetland#s annual review meeting.The Scottish government#s mental health minister Clare Haughey was attending the meeting, which was held on Monday afternoon.It came after NHS Shetland was forced to close six beds at the Gilbert Bain Hospital because of a recruitment shortfall.Director of nursing Kathleen Carolan said she hoped to have the shortage addressed within three months.Ms Haughey#s visit came after the crippling costs of travel and accommodation connected to locum medical cover was highlighted late last year.During the meeting she was challenged by Shetland integration joint board vice-chairman Allison Duncan.He warned that Shetland had spent £ million on locum cover over  months.#We already know that other local authorities like Dundee and other NHS debts are going to be written off. Will you write off any outstanding debts that we have here in Shetland # Mr Duncan said.The minister said she appreciated locum costs were #perhaps understandably high# but added that she was encouraged to hear of work done by the health board to train, recruitment and retain staff.#I was also interested to hear about the use of technology here in Shetland of #Attend Anywhere# [which uses Skype technology] and using video conferencing for accessing specialists on the mainland,# Ms Haughey said.NHS Shetland chief executive Ralph Roberts said #positive discussions# had been held with the Scottish government over the festive period #on how we can get support to recognise cost pressures we have had in the past year#.Earlier in the meeting Mr Roberts said good progress had been made in the last year, although he insisted the board was far from complacent.#We met our financial targets last year,# he said. #We have a small underspend and that was after we made some very signicant savings of over two and a half million pounds worth.#Mr Robertson said that meant the board could continue to invest in services where it needed to...

title: shetlands broadband among the worst
story: .The consumer affairs publication analysed speed checker data in all  Scottish council areas as well as England and Wales.At three megabits per second Orkney was found to have the slowest speeds in the country. Shetland came second from bottom in Scotland and third-last in the UK with speeds of .Mbps.The fastest speeds in Scotland are found in areas including West Dumbartonshire , Inverclydeand Dundee . Even the Western Isles, at .Mbps, has speeds nearly twice as fast as Shetland.List MSP Jamie Halcro Johnston said that the report highlighted a need for government investment in Shetland#s infrastructure.The Conservative member for the Highlands and Islands said: #I am disappointed to see Shetland lagging so far behind the rest of the country in broadband speeds. Shetland is getting a poor deal and it is rightly a matter of real concern for people here in the islands and across the Highlands and Islands.#I recognise Shetland’s unique geography, but to fulfil its own commitments the Scottish government must make it a priority to investment in the islands’ infrastructure – including broadband connectivity.#Paul Wheelhouse, minister for connectivity and the islands, said: #This report highlights what we already know – that it is more challenging to deliver and upgrade broadband infrastructure in rural areas.#The Scottish government has vowed to make sure all of Scotland has access to superfast broadbandby . Mr Wheelhouse said that  per cent of homes and businesses in Scotland already have access to superfast broadband. managing director of home products and services, said: #It’s incredibly frustrating that so many Scots are still struggling to get a good broadband connection when so many of us rely heavily on the internet to carry out important everyday tasks.#The Scottish Government must now press ahead with plans to provide  per cent of the homes in Scotland with a decent broadband connection and make sure that no one is at a disadvantage because of where they live.#..
